issue.title: Not able to get OQS-Chromium browser working - https://openquantumsafe.org/applications/tls.html#chromium
issue.body:
https://openquantumsafe.org/applications/tls.html#chromium
I am not able to use this Chromium browser testing any post Post-quantum servers like-  https://test.openquantumsafe.org:6028/.
Intially, I installed it on Ubuntu 20.04 but since this was not working then moved to Ubuntu 22.04, then also this is not working.

I really appreciate your attention in this matter.

comment.body:
Please note that OQS-BoringSSL doesn't support the algorithm used by port 6028, so OQS-Chromium can't open that website.

Please click [here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl?tab=readme-ov-file#supported-algorithms) to obtain the list of algorithms supported by OQS-Chromium.

We plan to update OQS-BoringSSL & OQS-Chromium in early March.

issue.title: Document & curate (O)IDs
issue.body:
The file [oqs-template/generate.yml](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/oqs-template/generate.yml) serves as the master file for all algorithm (O)IDs. Due to the absence of standard documents specifying them, most of the IDs chosen are randomly allocated, many manually, many automatically.

As persistence of PQC signature algorithms is a default feature of `oqsprovider`, OIDs for signature algorithms are manually curated and updated as OID updates are required, e.g., due to algorithm updates.

As persistence of PQC KEM algorithms is a non-default feature of `oqsprovider`, OIDs for KEM algorithms are mostly automatically generated and therefore not stable across releases.

This issue is to propose changing this with at least the following improvements:
- Document the origin for each (O)ID
- Change automatic OID allocation for KEM algorithms to manually curated allocation, paving the way for making [OQS_KEM_ENCODERS](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/CONFIGURE.md#oqs_kem_encoders) a default feature

comment.body:
I am a bit confused: [The IETF hackathon team decided to use the same OIDs for Kyber and ML-KEM](https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/pqc-certificates/issues/48), but I thought those algorithms are different (at least they have [different KATs](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/KATs/kem/kats.json)): Am I wrong in this assumption? This leads to a c[l|r]ash [when activating Kyber _and_ ML-KEM](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/actions/runs/8028844666/job/21934479575) using the same OID. Question to @praveksharma : Have you been part of the IETF hackathon team's decision to give Kyber and ML-KEM the same OIDs/supporting the notion they are functionally equivalent? Also tagging @bhess @dstebila for input.

If so, shall we (also follow the IETF hackathon's lead and) eliminate Kyber entirely from `oqsprovider`? Or shall we assign either algorithm different OIDs? Which ones? The ones used by the hackathon team IMO cannot be extended as they are in a range controlled by a commercial entity (prefix "1.3.6.1.4.1.").

May I propose @bhess takes on responsibility for managing the Kyber/Dilithium/ML-KEM/ML-DSA ID range and resolve this particular conundrum?

Given we have introduced the capability of encoding KEMs solely for interop testing (and to resolve https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/issues/194), what about adding a statement along the lines "This feature is experimental until a solid management of KEM OIDs is established. Use at your own risk." to the documentation of [OQS_KEM_ENCODERS](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/CONFIGURE.md#oqs_kem_encoders) and remove it from CI until we have properly resolved this issue? Also adding @Muzosh @ralienpp for input as they've been part of the discussions in #194.
